doc.title: BMGE

description.text: Block Mapping and Gathering using Entropy

doc.reference: Criscuolo A, Gribaldo S (2010) BMGE (Block Mapping and Gathering with Entropy): selection of phylogenetic informative regions from multiple sequence alignments. BMC Evolutionary Biology 10:210.

xhtml:div.xhtml:div: BMGE uses FASTA or PHYLIP sequential format for input. These are plain text files. There is no limit on the length of the alignment. There is also no limit on the length of the label of a sequence (i.e. its FASTA annotation line), although a too long label (e.g. more than 100 letters) will be truncated if the output format is PHYLIP sequential.

xhtml:div.label:
Type of sequence (-t)?
Set the input sequence coding Amino acid Nucleotide Codon
Both standard single-letter amino acid and nucleotide alphabets are used by BMGE. When using amino acid sequences, degenerated character states B and Z are understood by BMGE; similarly, degenerated nucleotide characters are also understood. The character state X is understood to be any of the 4 or 20 character states when using as input nucleotide or amino acid sequences, respectively. Dashes (i.e. '-') are understood as gaps, whereas dots (i.e. '.'), as any other single letter that are not inside standard alphabets, are considered as unknown character state (i.e. '?'). Nucleotide sequences can be set as codon ones. In this case, each successive nucleotide character triplet is considered as one codon character.

Similarity Matrices for amino acid and codon sequences (-m)?
BLOSUM62 Identity BLOSUM30 BLOSUM35 BLOSUM40 BLOSUM45 BLOSUM50 BLOSUM55 BLOSUM60 BLOSUM65 BLOSUM70 BLOSUM75 BLOSUM80 BLOSUM85 BLOSUM90 BLOSUM95
For each character, BMGE computes a score mainly determined by the entropy induced by the respective proportion of each residue. To estimate realistic scores that take into account biologically relevant substitution processes, BMGE weights the entropy estimation with substitution matrices.
These option can be used with the 15 estimated BLOSUM matrices. BMGE uses by default the popular BLOSUM62 matrix. The character trimming is progressively more stringent as the BLOSUM index increases (e.g. BLOSUM95); reciprocally, the trimming is progressively more relaxed as the BLOSUM index is lower (e.g. BLOSUM30). In practice, it is recommended to use BLOSUM95 with closely related sequences, and BLOSUM30 with distantly related sequences.
If input sequences are set as codons, BMGE performs a conversion into amino acid sequences (following the universal genetic code) and uses BLOSUM matrices to estimate the entropy-like score for each codon character. So, with option -t set as CODON, one can modify the option -m only with BLOSUM matrices. It is also possible to use the identity matrix with any sequence types.

Similarity Matrices for nucleotide sequences (-m)?
DNAPAM100 Identity DNAPAM1 DNAPAM5 DNAPAM10 DNAPAM20 DNAPAM30 DNAPAM40 DNAPAM50 DNAPAM60 DNAPAM70 DNAPAM80 DNAPAM90 DNAPAM110 DNAPAM120 DNAPAM130 DNAPAM140 DNAPAM150 DNAPAM160 DNAPAM170 DNAPAM180 DNAPAM190 DNAPAM200 DNAPAM210 DNAPAM220 DNAPAM230 DNAPAM240 DNAPAM250 DNAPAM260 DNAPAM270 DNAPAM280 DNAPAM290 DNAPAM300 DNAPAM310 DNAPAM320 DNAPAM330 DNAPAM340 DNAPAM350 DNAPAM360 DNAPAM370 DNAPAM380 DNAPAM390 DNAPAM400 DNAPAM410 DNAPAM420 DNAPAM430 DNAPAM440 DNAPAM450 DNAPAM460 DNAPAM470 DNAPAM480 DNAPAM490 DNAPAM500
For nucleotide input sequences, BMGE uses PAM matrices with a fixed transition/transition ratio. BMGE can be used with all possible PAM matrices, from the most stringent (i.e. DNAPAM1) to highly relaxed ones (e.g. DNAPAM500). By default with nucleotide sequences, BMGE uses the PAM-100 matrix.
It is also possible to use the identity matrix.

Transition/transversion ratio for nucleotide sequences.?
It is possible to indicate a transition/transversion ratio to better define the PAM matrices with nucleotide sequences. By default, BMGE uses a transition/transversion ratio of 2.

Gap Rate Cut-off (-g)?
BMGE allows characters containing too many gaps to be removed with this option. By default, BMGE removes all characters with a gap frequency greater than 0.2.

Minimum entropy Score Cut-off (-h)?
Following the smoothing operation of the entropy-like score values across characters, BMGE selects characters associated with a score value greater than a fixed threshold. This cut-off is set to 0.0 by default.

Maximum entropy Score Cut-off (-h)?
Following the smoothing operation of the entropy-like score values across characters, BMGE selects characters associated with a score value below a fixed threshold. This cut-off is set to 0.5 by default.

Minimum Block Size (-b)?
BMGE only selects regions of size greater than or equal to 5. Use this option to modify this minimum block size parameter.
Output in phylip sequential format (-op) Yes No

Output in phylip sequential format. Special formating (-oppp)?
Yes No
If input sequences are in FASTA format with NCBI-formatted annotation lines, e.g. >field1|field2|field3|field4| field5 [field6] the options -oppp allow naming sequences by field6_____field4 ; knowing that field4 is generally an accession number, and field6 a taxon name, this option leads to PHYLIP files where each sequence is labelled as a taxon name and an accession number.
Output in nexus format (-on) Yes No

Output in nexus format. Special formating (-onnn)?
Yes No
If input sequences are in FASTA format with NCBI-formatted annotation lines, e.g. >field1|field2|field3|field4| field5 [field6] the option -onnn allow naming sequences by field6_____field4 ; knowing that field4 is generally an accession number and field6 a taxon name, this option leads to NEXUS files where each sequence is labelled as a taxon name and an accession number.
Output in fasta format (-of) Yes No
Output in html format (-oh) Yes No

xhtml:div.xhtml:div: BMGE uses FASTA or PHYLIP sequential format for input. These are plain text files. There is no limit on the length of the alignment. There is also no limit on the length of the label of a sequence (i.e. its FASTA annotation line), although a too long label (e.g. more than 100 letters) will be truncated if the output format is PHYLIP sequential.

Both standard single-letter amino acid and nucleotide alphabets are used by BMGE. When using amino acid sequences, degenerated character states B and Z are understood by BMGE; similarly, degenerated nucleotide characters are also understood. The character state X is understood to be any of the 4 or 20 character states when using as input nucleotide or amino acid sequences, respectively. Dashes (i.e. '-') are understood as gaps, whereas dots (i.e. '.'), as any other single letter that are not inside standard alphabets, are considered as unknown character state (i.e. '?'). Nucleotide sequences can be set as codon ones. In this case, each successive nucleotide character triplet is considered as one codon character.

For each character, BMGE computes a score mainly determined by the entropy induced by the respective proportion of each residue. To estimate realistic scores that take into account biologically relevant substitution processes, BMGE weights the entropy estimation with substitution matrices.

These option can be used with the 15 estimated BLOSUM matrices. BMGE uses by default the popular BLOSUM62 matrix. The character trimming is progressively more stringent as the BLOSUM index increases (e.g. BLOSUM95); reciprocally, the trimming is progressively more relaxed as the BLOSUM index is lower (e.g. BLOSUM30). In practice, it is recommended to use BLOSUM95 with closely related sequences, and BLOSUM30 with distantly related sequences.

If input sequences are set as codons, BMGE performs a conversion into amino acid sequences (following the universal genetic code) and uses BLOSUM matrices to estimate the entropy-like score for each codon character. So, with option -t set as CODON, one can modify the option -m only with BLOSUM matrices. It is also possible to use the identity matrix with any sequence types.

For nucleotide input sequences, BMGE uses PAM matrices with a fixed transition/transition ratio. BMGE can be used with all possible PAM matrices, from the most stringent (i.e. DNAPAM1) to highly relaxed ones (e.g. DNAPAM500). By default with nucleotide sequences, BMGE uses the PAM-100 matrix.
It is also possible to use the identity matrix.
It is possible to indicate a transition/transversion ratio to better define the PAM matrices with nucleotide sequences. By default, BMGE uses a transition/transversion ratio of 2.
BMGE allows characters containing too many gaps to be removed with this option. By default, BMGE removes all characters with a gap frequency greater than 0.2.

Following the smoothing operation of the entropy-like score values across characters, BMGE selects characters associated with a score value greater than a fixed threshold. This cut-off is set to 0.0 by default.

Following the smoothing operation of the entropy-like score values across characters, BMGE selects characters associated with a score value below a fixed threshold. This cut-off is set to 0.5 by default.
BMGE only selects regions of size greater than or equal to 5. Use this option to modify this minimum block size parameter.

If input sequences are in FASTA format with NCBI-formatted annotation lines, e.g. >field1|field2|field3|field4| field5 [field6] the options -oppp allow naming sequences by field6_____field4 ; knowing that field4 is generally an accession number, and field6 a taxon name, this option leads to PHYLIP files where each sequence is labelled as a taxon name and an accession number.

If input sequences are in FASTA format with NCBI-formatted annotation lines, e.g. >field1|field2|field3|field4| field5 [field6] the option -onnn allow naming sequences by field6_____field4 ; knowing that field4 is generally an accession number and field6 a taxon name, this option leads to NEXUS files where each sequence is labelled as a taxon name and an accession number.

Dashes (i.e. '-') are understood as gaps, whereas dots (i.e. '.'), as any other single letter that are not inside standard alphabets, are considered as unknown character state (i.e. '?'). Nucleotide sequences can be set as codon ones. In this case, each successive nucleotide character triplet is considered as one codon character.

parameter.name: matrixaa
parameter.prompt: Similarity Matrices for amino acid and codon sequences (-m)

comment.text: For each character, BMGE computes a score mainly determined by the entropy induced by the respective proportion of each residue. To estimate realistic scores that take into account biologically relevant substitution processes, BMGE weights the entropy estimation with substitution matrices.

These option can be used with the 15 estimated BLOSUM matrices. BMGE uses by default the popular BLOSUM62 matrix. The character trimming is progressively more stringent as the BLOSUM index increases (e.g. BLOSUM95); reciprocally, the trimming is progressively more relaxed as the BLOSUM index is lower (e.g. BLOSUM30). In practice, it is recommended to use BLOSUM95 with closely related sequences, and BLOSUM30 with distantly related sequences.

If input sequences are set as codons, BMGE performs a conversion into amino acid sequences (following the universal genetic code) and uses BLOSUM matrices to estimate the entropy-like score for each codon character. So, with option -t set as CODON, one can modify the option -m only with BLOSUM matrices. It is also possible to use the identity matrix with any sequence types.

interface.label:

BLOSUM62 Identity BLOSUM30 BLOSUM35 BLOSUM40 BLOSUM45 BLOSUM50 BLOSUM55 BLOSUM60 BLOSUM65 BLOSUM70 BLOSUM75 BLOSUM80 BLOSUM85 BLOSUM90 BLOSUM95
For each character, BMGE computes a score mainly determined by the entropy induced by the respective proportion of each residue. To estimate realistic scores that take into account biologically relevant substitution processes, BMGE weights the entropy estimation with substitution matrices.
These option can be used with the 15 estimated BLOSUM matrices. BMGE uses by default the popular BLOSUM62 matrix. The character trimming is progressively more stringent as the BLOSUM index increases (e.g. BLOSUM95); reciprocally, the trimming is progressively more relaxed as the BLOSUM index is lower (e.g. BLOSUM30). In practice, it is recommended to use BLOSUM95 with closely related sequences, and BLOSUM30 with distantly related sequences.
If input sequences are set as codons, BMGE performs a conversion into amino acid sequences (following the universal genetic code) and uses BLOSUM matrices to estimate the entropy-like score for each codon character. So, with option -t set as CODON, one can modify the option -m only with BLOSUM matrices. It is also possible to use the identity matrix with any sequence types.

BMGE can be used with all possible PAM matrices, from the most stringent (i.e. DNAPAM1) to highly relaxed ones (e.g. DNAPAM500). By default with nucleotide sequences, BMGE uses the PAM-100 matrix.
It is also possible to use the identity matrix.

interface.label:
Similarity Matrices for nucleotide sequences (-m)?
DNAPAM100 Identity DNAPAM1 DNAPAM5 DNAPAM10 DNAPAM20 DNAPAM30 DNAPAM40 DNAPAM50 DNAPAM60 DNAPAM70 DNAPAM80 DNAPAM90 DNAPAM110 DNAPAM120 DNAPAM130 DNAPAM140 DNAPAM150 DNAPAM160 DNAPAM170 DNAPAM180 DNAPAM190 DNAPAM200 DNAPAM210 DNAPAM220 DNAPAM230 DNAPAM240 DNAPAM250 DNAPAM260 DNAPAM270 DNAPAM280 DNAPAM290 DNAPAM300 DNAPAM310 DNAPAM320 DNAPAM330 DNAPAM340 DNAPAM350 DNAPAM360 DNAPAM370 DNAPAM380 DNAPAM390 DNAPAM400 DNAPAM410 DNAPAM420 DNAPAM430 DNAPAM440 DNAPAM450 DNAPAM460 DNAPAM470 DNAPAM480 DNAPAM490 DNAPAM500

It is also possible to use the identity matrix.

Transition/transversion ratio for nucleotide sequences.?
It is possible to indicate a transition/transversion ratio to better define the PAM matrices with nucleotide sequences. By default, BMGE uses a transition/transversion ratio of 2.

message.text: The value must be between 0 and 1

comment.text: BMGE allows characters containing too many gaps to be removed with this option. By default, BMGE removes all characters with a gap frequency greater than 0.2.

interface.label:
Gap Rate Cut-off (-g)?
BMGE allows characters containing too many gaps to be removed with this option. By default, BMGE removes all characters with a gap frequency greater than 0.2.

xhtml:div.xhtml:div: BMGE allows characters containing too many gaps to be removed with this option. By default, BMGE removes all characters with a gap frequency greater than 0.2.

format.code: ("", " -h %s:%s " % ( value, max_entropy) )[ (max_entropy != 0.5 or value !=vdef) and (max_entropy > value) ]

message.text: The value must be between 0 and 1

comment.text: Following the smoothing operation of the entropy-like score values across characters, BMGE selects characters associated with a score value greater than a fixed threshold. This cut-off is set to 0.0 by default.

interface.label:
Minimum entropy Score Cut-off (-h)?
Following the smoothing operation of the entropy-like score values across characters, BMGE selects characters associated with a score value greater than a fixed threshold. This cut-off is set to 0.0 by default.

xhtml:div.xhtml:div: Following the smoothing operation of the entropy-like score values across characters, BMGE selects characters associated with a score value greater than a fixed threshold. This cut-off is set to 0.0 by default.

message.text: The value must be between 0 and 1 and greather than minimun entropy score

comment.text: Following the smoothing operation of the entropy-like score values across characters, BMGE selects characters associated with a score value below a fixed threshold. This cut-off is set to 0.5 by default.

Maximum entropy Score Cut-off (-h)?
Following the smoothing operation of the entropy-like score values across characters, BMGE selects characters associated with a score value below a fixed threshold. This cut-off is set to 0.5 by default.

interface.label: Output in phylip sequential format (-op) Yes No

parameter.name: phylip_oppp
parameter.prompt: Output in phylip sequential format. Special formating (-oppp)

comment.text: If input sequences are in FASTA format with NCBI-formatted annotation lines, e.g. >field1|field2|field3|field4| field5 [field6] the options -oppp allow naming sequences by field6_____field4 ; knowing that field4 is generally an accession number, and field6 a taxon name, this option leads to PHYLIP files where each sequence is labelled as a taxon name and an accession number.

interface.label:
Output in phylip sequential format. Special formating (-oppp)?
Yes No
If input sequences are in FASTA format with NCBI-formatted annotation lines, e.g. >field1|field2|field3|field4| field5 [field6] the options -oppp allow naming sequences by field6_____field4 ; knowing that field4 is generally an accession number, and field6 a taxon name, this option leads to PHYLIP files where each sequence is labelled as a taxon name and an accession number.

interface.label: Output in nexus format (-on) Yes No

parameter.name: nexus_onnn
parameter.prompt: Output in nexus format. Special formating (-onnn)

comment.text: If input sequences are in FASTA format with NCBI-formatted annotation lines, e.g. >field1|field2|field3|field4| field5 [field6] the option -onnn allow naming sequences by field6_____field4 ; knowing that field4 is generally an accession number and field6 a taxon name, this option leads to NEXUS files where each sequence is labelled as a taxon name and an accession number.

interface.label:
Output in nexus format. Special formating (-onnn)?
Yes No
If input sequences are in FASTA format with NCBI-formatted annotation lines, e.g. >field1|field2|field3|field4| field5 [field6] the option -onnn allow naming sequences by field6_____field4 ; knowing that field4 is generally an accession number and field6 a taxon name, this option leads to NEXUS files where each sequence is labelled as a taxon name and an accession number.

interface.label: Output in fasta format (-of) Yes No
Output in html format (-oh) Yes No
